title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: His gossip, Mersington, would no doubt have obtained a comfortable sharo of "the compensations " in 1707, had he

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: " Nought but letters from the exiled lords and gentlemen ; some of them, I tell thee, Mersington, are deeply touching, and would harrow up even that impenetrable heart of thine.

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: " Surrender, ye d d loons ! " cried Mersington, " or hee hee, we'll gie ye cauld kail through the reek, conform to the Acts of Estate."

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: Thou mayest go to the devil, Mersington, with thy drunken scrawl, the address, and the council to boot.

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: The subtle Mersington, the proud earl of Perth, the reckless  Lord Clermistonlee, and others of the haughty council, were made aware of all this by their numerous spies ; but the formidable tribunal which had so long ruled the land by the sword and gibbet, was now completely paralysed by the appearance  of many " sulky blue bonnets " crowding the streets ; they failed to arrest a single individual, though treason, like a hundred-headed hydra, stalked in daylight through their thoroughfares, and declaimed in their public places.

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: No man shall assume the part of monitor to me ! Again and again I have told thee, Mersington, that my whole soul, for this year past, has been bent upon the possession of Lilian Napier, and her acres of wood and wold ; and dost think, gossip, that I, who have subdued so many fine women (yea, and some deuced haughty ones, too), shall be baffled by a little moppet like this ? Come, good gossip, assist me with thy advice.

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: " Ou' aye, ou' aye !" muttered Mersington, as he buried his weason face in the tankard.

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: The lord high treasurer, the chancellor, and the sleepy Mersington, withdrew as our hero entered.

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: And so, Mersington, you wifl uot ride with us to-night ?"

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: " Either the cantrips o' Beatrix Gilruth, or Lucky Elshender (baith o' whom are weel deserving p' the branks and tar barrel, Mersington), hae clean bewitched that puir beast.

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: But I am getting desperate, Mersington ; between love of the girl, lack of her lands, and fear of poverty, nothing now can save me but a dash."

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: " Hold, Mersington ! I beg you will hear me with gravity.

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: " He, he ! " chuckled Mersington, " I have heard you say the same o' twenty.

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: " Hush, Mersington, you jest too much on this matter.

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: " Hee, hee ! " chuckled Mersington.

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: " Tush ! I will hare him under the nippers of the lord advocate ere long ; when his head is on yonder battlements* of the Nether Bow, the barony of Bruntisfield goes to Lilian Napier ; and dost think, Mersington, that chitti-faced girl will stand in my way P I trow not.

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: " Ou aye ou aye he ! he !" chuckled Mersington.

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: "Be seated, Mersington.

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: " Anent whilk it is needless to expone," interposed Mersington.

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: " Since the cold-blooded atrocities this chamber has witnessed,"  began Claverhouse, turning his eyes of fire on the law lord ; but the entrance of Pincer and his two subaltern torturers, whom that little viper, Mersington, had summoned, cut short the observation.

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: " Aye, the boot ! " said Rosehaugh, Mersington, and one or two others.

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: In those days the hour of dinner was about one or two o'clock ; but as the earl of Perth, the lords Clermistonlee, Mersington, and others loved their wine too well to leave it soon for dry matters of state, and the thumbscrewing of witches and nonconformists, the evening was far advanced before Walter Fenton was summoned for examination in the Laigh chamber, where the council held their meetings under the parliament hall, in a dark and gloomy region, where lights are always burned even yet during the longest days of summer.
